The construction of this variable exploits the overall panel provided to us by the customs, that goes back to 1995. A.2 Variables recovered from external sources In Tables 7 and 10, we use various firm-level variables to document the heterogeneity in pricing strategies across French firms. We rely on the INSEE-Ficus dataset, which provides balance-sheet data covering the universe of French firms. We merge the dataset with the trade variable, using the French firm Siren identifier. Sector. Based on the balance-sheet data, we can recover information on the firmÃÂ¢Ãâ¬Ãâ¢s sector of activity, as defined in the NAF nomenclature. We use this information to construct the ÃÂ¢Ãâ¬ÃÅWholesalerÃÂ¢Ãâ¬ÃÂ and ÃÂ¢Ãâ¬ÃÅRetailerÃÂ¢Ãâ¬ÃÂ dummies introduced in column (3) of Table 7.

Relative Sales. The ÃÂ¢Ãâ¬ÃÅRelative SalesÃÂ¢Ãâ¬ÃÂ variable in Table 7 is measured as the ratio of the firmÃÂ¢Ãâ¬Ãâ¢s overall turnover divided by the median turnover of firms active in the same sector of activity. We get rid of the time dimension by calculating this ratio for a single cross-section, namely, 2006. The variable thus captures the relative size of the firm, in its sector. The ÃÂ¢Ãâ¬ÃÅLarge firmÃÂ¢Ãâ¬ÃÂ dummy used in Tables 5 and 10 is constructed from this variable and is equal to 1 for the top four firms in each sector. Relative Market Power. The ÃÂ¢Ãâ¬ÃÅRelative Market PowerÃÂ¢Ãâ¬ÃÂ variable is defined based on information on the ratio of the firmÃÂ¢Ãâ¬Ãâ¢s gross operating surplus over its value added, expressed in relative terms with respect to the median firm in the sector.

Here as well, the variable has no time dimension and 2006 is used as reference. The ÃÂ¢Ãâ¬ÃÅHigh Market PowerÃÂ¢Ãâ¬ÃÂ dummy used in Table 5 is constructed from this variable and is equal to 1 for the top 25% of firms in each sector.
